item.title: Texas shatters voter registration records again as election draws closer
item.description: Texas now has 16.6 million voters, an increase of more than 400,000 since March. And since 2016, Texas has added 1.5 million voters to its rolls.

item.title: Toward a "modern" Emacs
item.description: It has only been a few months since the Emacs community went through an extended discussion on how to make the Emacs editor "popular again". As the community gears up for the Emacs 28 development cycle, (after the Emacs 27.1 release in August) that discussion has returned with a vengeance. The themes of this discussion differ somewhat from the last; developers are concerned about making Emacs — an editor with decades of history — seem "modern" to attract new users.
item.author: (By Jonathan CorbetSeptember 25, 2020)

item.title: Pluralsight Editing: Behind the Scenes
item.description:
Support More Content: https://www.patreon.com/codewithsteve https://www.buymeacoffee.com/stevejgordon
In this video, I show the editing process I follow when creating a clip for a Pluralsight module. In this example, I use Camtasia to edit together the audio and video for the first clip for my upcoming course "Implementing Cross-Cutting Concerns for ASP.NET Core Microservices".
Pluralsight Content: https://app.pluralsight.com/profile/author/steve-gordon Twitter: @stevejgordon Web: stevejgordon.co.uk
#aspnetcore #dotnet #behindthescenes #training
item.author: (Code With Steve)

item.title: Bypassing Android MDM using Electromagnetic Fault Injection by a Gas Lighter for $1.5
item.description: This blog talks about how we bypassed the android manufacturer implemented firmware based MDM solution using nothing but a 1.5$ gas lighter and some patience.

item.description: I made these six doodles. A neural network guessed 6 of them correctly. How many of yours can it guess?

item.title: ML.NET September Updates | .NET Blog
item.description: ML.NET is an open-source, cross-platform machine learning framework for .NET developers. It enables integrating machine learning into your .NET apps without requiring you to leave the .NET ecosystem or even have a background in ML or data science. ML.NET provides tooling (Model Builder UI in Visual Studio and the cross platform ML.NET CLI) that automatically trains custom machine learning models for you based on your scenario and data.
item.author: (Bri Achtman Program Manager, .NET Follow)

item.title: Desktop Community Standup - Sept 24th 2020 - Open source development for WinForms
item.description:
In this episode of Desktop Community Standup you will meet some of our key OSS contributors and the WinForms team members working with public PRs. We will talk about the process of submitting, reviewing and accepting PRs and other nuances of OSS development.
Community Links: https://www.theurlist.com/desktop-standup-2020-09-24
Featuring: Olia Gavrysh (@oliagavrysh), Igor Velikorossov (@IgorRussKie), Hugh Bellamy, Tobias Käs
item.author: (.NET Foundation)

item.title: Swift System is Now Open Source
item.description: In June, Apple introduced Swift System, a new library for Apple platforms that provides idiomatic interfaces to system calls and low-level currency types. Today, I’m excited to announce that we’re open-sourcing System and adding Linux support! Our vision is for System to eventually act as the single home for low-level system interfaces for all supported Swift platforms.
item.author: (Apple Inc.)

item.title: IntelliCode Team Completions
item.description: Visual Studio IntelliCode uses machine learning to offer useful, contextually rich code completion suggestion, in-line as you code. In this episode, PM Caty Caldwell shows a new feature of IntelliCode

item.title: Angie Jones - Keynote: The Reality of Developing an Artificial World [w/ASL Interpreting]
item.description:
Our world is changing. Artificial intelligence is being employed in just about all walks of life - from virtual assistants to self-driving cars. How does this new way of life impact software development?
In this talk, Angie will share her personal journey in learning how to test the AI-based applications that we develop, and highlight just how important it is to society that we get this right. --- Angie Jones is a Senior Developer Advocate who specializes in test automation strategies and techniques. She shares her wealth of knowledge by speaking and teaching at software conferences all over the world, writing tutorials and technical articles on angiejones.tech, and leading the online learning platform, Test Automation University.
As a Master Inventor, Angie is known for her innovative and out-of-the-box thinking style which has resulted in more than 25 patented inventions in the US and China. In her spare time, Angie volunteers with Black Girls Code to teach coding workshops to young girls in an effort to attract more women and minorities to tech.
Angie on Twitter: https://twitter.com/techgirl1908
item.author: (JuneteenthConf)

item.title: Things Elixir's Phoenix Framework Does Right
item.description: I dabbled in Phoenix for a while now, but never really got my hands dirty with it right up until now. Apart from the whole framework being surprisingly well thought through, there are a few things that strike me as being done exceptionally well in Phoenix, compared to the rest of modern web frameworks. 1. Striking a balance between flexibility and strictness Modern web frameworks can be roughly divided into two camps:

item.title: The failed promise of Web Components – Lea Verou
item.description: Web Components had so much potential to empower HTML to do more, and make web development more accessible to non-programmers and easier for programmers. Remember how exciting it was every time we got new shiny HTML elements that actually do stuff? Remember how exciting it was to be able to do sliders, color pickers, dialogs, disclosure widgets straight in the HTML, without having to include any widget libraries?
